awd_titl_txt: Understanding the effects of above- and belowground linkages on carbon cycling in a high latitude, coastal wetland
awd_abstract_narration:
The Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta of western Alaska is one of the largest river deltas in the world and the summer home to millions of migratory birds. Although grazing birds strongly affect the plant communities in river deltas, little is known about how changing waterfowl populations in the Arctic affect the release from soils of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane. This project is examining  relationships among grazing birds, plant communities, soil microbes, and ecosystem carbon cycling in the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta to predict how these ecosystems may change in the future. This project will produce on-line learning modules about the relationships among geese, plants, microbes, and greenhouse gases and disseminate them to middle school students in the local Alaskan school district. Local students will also be trained in and produce local radio stories about the research. Finally, the research will be broadcasted through on-line media outlets and local TV channels. 
 
This project is using a combination of field experiments, lab experiments, and biogeochemical models to provide a mechanistic understanding of the effects of grazing on greenhouse gas dynamics in a high latitude coastal wetland. This project is quantifying the independent and combined effects of grazing, trampling, and feces deposition by geese on microbial communities, soil microclimate, and carbon dynamics using a two-year field experiment. A laboratory experiment is being used to quantify how herbivore-mediated changes in the quantity and quality of soil carbon inputs affect microbial community structure and carbon dynamics. Finally, results from these experiments are being used to parameterize a biogeochemical simulation model to predict how changes in herbivory will affect carbon dynamics in subarctic wet sedge under future climates. By examining the effects of herbivory with this holistic view, the predictive power of ecosystem models will be increased, especially for high-latitude systems where herbivory is a prevalent driver of primary production and plant community composition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how migratory geese shape the way carbon moves through sub-Arctic wetlands—an important question as the climate warms and animal behaviors shift in response. Conducted in Alaska’s Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta, a vast and ecologically rich tidal wetland in the sub-Arctic, our research focused on how goose activities such as grazing, trampling, and feces additions affect plant growth, soil microbes, and the storage or release of carbon in these sensitive ecosystems.

Through a combination of field experiments, laboratory studies, and computer simulations, we discovered that geese play a major role in altering how carbon is cycled and stored. In the field, we manipulated goose impacts over two growing seasons and found that grazing, the removal of plant material, consistently reduced plant productivity and turned areas into net carbon sources, meaning they released more carbon than they stored. Trampling and fecal deposition had more variable effects, but still contributed to important changes in plant growth, soil chemistry, and microbial communities.

We also looked closely at the soil microbes that help regulate carbon and nutrient cycles. Using genetic tools to study bacteria and fungi in the soil, we found that grazing significantly changed microbial community composition and function. Our results showed that grazing had the strongest impact, shifting the makeup of microbial communities and enhancing their potential to cycle nutrients like nitrogen and phosphorus. Grazing also made microbial communities more similar across different sites by influencing how microbes spread and establish. These changes suggest that herbivory not only alters which microbes are present, but also how they function in breaking down organic matter and recycling nutrients.

In a tightly controlled lab experiment, we investigated how changes in the quality and quantity of plant material, caused by herbivores, affect microbial activity and carbon emissions from soil. We found that both the type of plant material (whether it was nutrient-rich or old and decaying) and how much was added had a strong effect on the amount of carbon dioxide released. Microbial communities responded differently depending on the litter type, especially when feces or nutrient-poor material were added. These results demonstrate that animal-driven changes to plant litter quantity and quality can shape microbial processes and greenhouse gas emissions in complex ways.

To help us understand how herbivore-mediated changes to wetland soils and microbial communities may unfold over time and under future climate conditions, we developed a computer model specifically adapted for sub-Arctic wetlands. This model enabled us to simulate the impact of grazing and climate change on carbon and nitrogen storage in soils. We found that while grazed and ungrazed wetlands can hold similar amounts of soil carbon under current conditions, grazed wetlands are more vulnerable to drying caused by climate change. In some cases, grazed areas could lose up to 69% of their soil carbon under moderate warming and drying, compared to just 23% in ungrazed areas. These results highlight the need to include both animal impacts and climate variables when predicting how sub-Arctic wetlands will respond to global change.

This project also contributed significantly to both education and public engagement by developing classroom-ready science materials that incorporate real sub-Arctic research, expanding access to climate science for K–12 students and educators. Outreach efforts included workshops, webinars, and a suite of multimedia resources that helped connect diverse audiences, particularly in Alaska and northern communities, to ecological research and its relevance to climate change. The project also provided meaningful training and career development opportunities for students and early-career professionals, emphasizing science communication, fieldwork, and media production.

Importantly, the research highlighted how animal behavior can influence greenhouse gas dynamics, adding a new dimension to our understanding of climate feedbacks. These findings support more integrated climate and conservation policies that consider the ecological roles of wildlife. Overall, the project bridged science, education, and policy in ways that foster broader societal understanding of climate-related ecosystem change.
